body:
run java8 tests
run cpp tests
@massakam The change LGTM. It would be nice to have a test that reproduces this issue in the Mocked managed ledger tests, to ensure we won't have a regression in the future.
it looks like c++ client lib is missing

@templarzq pulsar go client is a cgo wrapper over existing cpp client. currently we only provide cpp client for mac and linux. it doesn't support windows yet.

You can check out more details about go client here : http://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/client-libraries-go/
@sijie You are right, I may have described it incorrectly.
好的，请问有windows的go client开发计划吗？
@sijie I can try to implement it, because in other projects, I have implemented it.

@kuangye098 that’s awesome. Since it is big feature, it would be good that you can write a PIP (pulsar improvement proposal) to describe your proposal of changes. Then we can discuss in details. 

Here is wiki page for all the pulsar PIPs. You can check out how other people wrote them https://github.com/apache/pulsar/wiki
@sijie Is dns necessary, or can we use IP address directly?
@sijie OK，I will read it carefully and then write a PIP to describe the proposal of changes.

@templarzq I think we just need to make the c++ client be able to compile on windows. Then you are able to use the go client. However most of the committers don't really use windows here, so it would take a while for us to support windows.

@sfescape the Reader and Consumer API does have this functionality:

reader.hasReachedEndOfTopic()
In looking at the Websocket API documentation, I don't see anything in the endpoint responses that give me that information. I understand it's available in the other interfaces.
#2688 This is the master ticket to tracking this PR

It's not ultra critical, as after a little reading it's possible to exclude these classes from detection.

That said I find it perplexing that different versions of the same dependencies would be being utilised!

run cpp tests
run java8 tests

run cpp tests
run java8 tests

run java8 tests
run cpp tests
This problem can be avoided by https://github.com/apache/pulsar/pull/2673

run cpp tests
run java8 tests
@merlimat which unit tests were failing because of this?

rerun cpp tests
rerun integration tests
rerun java8 tests

> @merlimat which unit tests were failing because of this? 

I was debugging the `RawReaderTest` in which the assertion was failing because of duplicated messages. It was because of the out-of-order acks that the client was re-sending some of the messages. But I saw the assertion failure at https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/48431543729fc4f382637c968976d0d164d5427b/managed-ledger/src/main/java/org/apache/bookkeeper/mledger/impl/OpAddEntry.java#L143 in the logs of several other flaky unit tests in last week.
@rdhabalia The reason this is separated is to avoid mixing the dependencies. Since the presto worker runs with a different classpath, we can avoid dealing with all the conflicts.
In any case.. yes the deploy issue should be fixed..
ok.. then let me try to test by adding `wagon-ssh-external` plugin.
@sfescape Currently this feature is not available in websocket. you can check this out for the feature parity between clients: https://github.com/apache/pulsar/wiki/Client-Features-Matrix
Thank you, this feature seems to be "Reader hasMessageAvailable". This project doesn't seem to use JIRA, is there a place I can go look for any roadmap on websocket API features?

@sfescape we are using github issues for the issue management. the wiki page is for tracking the feature parity. we are currently catching up on c++ and python (we are almost caught up there). however regarding websocket, it is still in the backlog. we put that in low priority since there is no real asks before. we will try to prioritize it since now we are seeing requests.
So is this the root cause of the RawReaderTest failure?
Yes, I was able to reproduce easily when running in a Docker container in MacOS (thus inside a slowing VM)

dunno if it's available for mac bit stress-ng is great for this.

It would be good to have the fixed tests mentioned in the commit message, but I guess it's too late now.

as what I explained in slack channel, we need to carefully think about this. sure we can introduce anything we like in java function, but what does that mean to other languages. this change will either inconsistency between languages, or introduce complexity on maintaining consistency between languages. and it will just make things much confused than a simple function interface.
The target java community will want popular function interfaces to be represented in our sdk, which is only a handful, I don't think we want to  restrict the sdk to a single interface.
since I prefer simplicity and consistency across languages, I am -0 on this change. however if other people feel this is needed, go for it.

I would suggest add this only if there is actual user demand.  Writing a function "Function<Foo, Void>" vs "Consumer<Foo>" isn't that much different, but now we have to also to consider "Consumer" interface in java function runtime which will add complexity.  

Also if we add the consumer interface, it only makes sense to add one for SDK as well as allow users to submit the raw java.util.Consumer as well
@jerrypeng Can you check that the license header is fine when starting the presto worker?

also according to this doc: https://github.com/apache/pulsar/wiki/Release-Candidate-Validation
we don't see `apache-pulsar-io-connectors*` under `apache-pulsar-<release>`
@sijie Can you rebase/merge with master -- That should have fixed several of the flaky tests
